Ordering parameters are enclosed in curved brackets, labelling parameters in square brackets, and extra parameters between angle brackets.

Note that not all optional parameters are meaningful for all existing commands. Some commands may, for instance, accept only an order and/or a label parameter, while others accept only extra parameters. In fact, no command exists that accepts all three classes of optional parameters, and there are several which accept none. Tab. 11 lists the classes accepted for each of all existing commands, both simple and environment ones. An exact definition of the terms used is shown in Tab. 10.

Permission Definition
≈ The parameter is optional, but may not be empty if present.
≈ø The parameter is optional, and may be empty.
✔ The parameter is mandatory, and it may not be empty.
✔ø The parameter is mandatory, but it may be empty.
✘ The parameter is altogether forbidden.
✘ø The parameter is forbidden, unless it is empty.

Tab. 10:

Definition of the various permissions. These terms are used in Tab. 11.

As the Tab. 11 below confirms, it is always possible to specify empty extra parameters for any command. This is done so that token concatenation is possible for simple commands that take no primary parameters, as is often the case with user-defined macros. A practical application of this feature is described in Section 31.

Command Order Label Extra
\answer ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\appendix ✘ ≈ ✘ø
\bibliography ✘ ≈ ✘ø
\body ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\bold ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\br ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\caps ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\cite ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\code ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\del ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\foot ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\head ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\image ✘ ✘ ≈ø (frame, width)
\ins ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\item ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\link ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\mbox ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\mref ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\notes ✘ ≈ ✘ø
\paragraph ✘ ✘ ≈ø (initial, indent)
\part ✘ø/✔ø ≈ ✘ø
\question ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\ranswer ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\ref ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\rquestion ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\rule ✘ ✘ ✘ø
\section ✘ø/✔ø ≈ ✘ø

Tab. 11:

The permissions associated with the various lambtex commands for each of the three classes (order, label, and extra) of optional arguments. In the case of extra parameters, the options available for each command are also displayed. Note that simple commands are shown prefixed with a backslash, whereas environment commands are enclosed inside brackets. Within each category, commands are shown alphabetically. Furthermore, the commands boxout and theorem are shown in italics because the actual command name is user-defined.

DNotes on ordering in the context of sub-pages

This section applies to those blocks that have an associated ordering, namely wrapper blocks, sectional blocks, and the custom blocks (boxouts and theorems). Recall that a wrapper is essentially a floater element with a caption and an order associated with it. There are four elements in lambtex that fit into this category: equations, printouts, tables, and figures. As for sectional blocks, these are the ones that produce parts, sections, sub-sections, and sub-sub-sections. There are some special — though as you shall see based on common sense — rules that must be followed concerning the order parameter and the hyperlinking of blocks with associated ordering, particularly in the context of sub-pages. The rules are as follows:

  1. Only numbered elements may be referred to using \ref and \sref commands:

    Unless the user explicitly demanded an empty ordering, sectional commands have by default a number. As for wrappers, they always have an associated order. In the case of custom environments, the situation varies.

    It makes sense that the hyperlinking commands that are supposed to produce a number should only be used with wrappers, numbered sectional blocks, or numbered custom environments. These commands are \ref and \sref. On the other hand, because \mref does not output a number, it is always allowed.

  2. You must explicitly provide a manual ordering for sub-paged wrappers, sectional blocks, or custom blocks:

    A sub-paged element is one that is declared inside a subpage block (see Section 15). Because they lie outside the main flow of the document, these elements are not automatically numbered. You must therefore explicitly provide them with an ordering parameter. This is done by inserting the numbering between parentheses. Note that in the case of sectional commands or custom blocks an empty ordering is allowed.

  3. You may not provide a manual ordering for wrappers, sectional blocks, or custom blocks defined outside a sub-page:

    This rule is complementary to the previous one. Because these blocks are numbered automatically by lambtex when present in the main document, you may not interfere with that automatism by providing an explicit ordering. Note, however, that an empty ordering is always allowed for sectional commands or custom blocks.

EExtra parameters

Remember that extra parameters are those enclosed between angle brackets, and always precede any mandatory parameters the command may have. Canonically, specifying that a parameter alpha should have a value x is done by declaring alpha=x as the extra parameter. Should the command accept multiple parameters, these can be separated by inserting a ',' (comma) between them. Tab. 12 below lists all the existing extra parameters together with the accepted values for each.

Parameter Accepted values
initial Boolean
indent Boolean or auto
box Boolean
linenums Boolean
zebra Boolean
mult Integer between 0 and 9 (inclusive)
frame Boolean
width Integer between 1 and 100 (inclusive), or auto
bul Discrete values: disc, circle, square, none
num Discrete values: 0, i, I, a, A, decimal, lower-roman, upper-roman, lower-alpha, upper-alpha, none
float Discrete values: center, left, right
class A class name specification
lang Discrete values: ocaml, c, java, etc (any value accepted by the camlhighlight library)

Tab. 12:

List of all existing extra parameters and associated range of values. Consult Tab. 11 for a list of which of these parameters are accepted for each command.

Note that for brevity sake, lambtex allows shorthand forms to be specified instead of the canonical form. The shorthand pre-conditions are as follows:

  1. It suffices to declare a value if there is no ambiguity as to which parameter it belongs to. In the example above this means declaring simply x instead of alpha=x. Because lambtex knows which values are valid for each parameter, and because there are practically no overlaps in the existing set of commands, this condition applies almost always. The notable exception is the environment command source, which accepts three different boolean parameters (see Tab. 11).

  2. Boolean parameters may be set by specifying the parameter name. Therefore, if parameter beta is boolean, you may set it to true by declaring either beta, beta=true, beta=y, or if there are no other boolean parameters accepted for the command, just true or y. Similarly, a boolean parameter may be unset by prefixing it with '!'. Therefore, setting beta to false can be done by declaring either !beta, beta=false, beta=n, or if there is no chance of conflict, just false or n.

  3. When setting multiple extra parameters, if one of the settings is provided in canonical form or as a boolean parameter name, then it can be used to constrain an otherwise ambiguous declaration. Consider thus a command that takes two boolean extra parameters, alpha and beta. Only providing the sequence true is ambiguous, because lambtex has no way of knowing to which parameter it refers. However, specifying !alpha,true is not ambiguous, because this can only be interpreted as setting parameter alpha to false, and the remaining parameter — which can only be beta — to true.

As can be deduced from the above rules, lambtex uses a basic constraint satisfaction algorithm to resolve extra parameter declarations. If the declaration is unambiguous to a human, so it should be to lambtex.

Backmatter

Notes

  1. (1)

    As stated, any given command may either be expressed by the simple notation or as an environment. This should be interpreted an exclusive-or condition, meaning that no command exists that can be expressed as both. However, the choice of adopting one or the other notation was not an arbitrary one. Due to its syntactic terseness, the simple notation was preferred. The more verbose environment notation was chosen only for those commands that satisfied at least one of the two following conditions:

    • The command may be the parent of at least one block-level element.

    • The command declares a verbatim-like environment using the heredoc technique for delimitation (see Section 10 for an example).

  2. (2)

    While the qualifier typically implies a degree of uncertainty concerning the optionality of these parameters, in practice you may treat them as truly optional. The qualifier exists because there is one (and only one!) exception, which applies to environments not normally used in regular documents. Namely, inside sub-pages the order parameter is mandatory for a number of blocks (see Appendix D for details).

  3. (3)

    Note that in most practical situations you can get away with inputting an ampersand directly without escaping. This is because the scanner will only interpret an ampersand as the beginning of an entity declaration if it is immediately followed by an alphabetic or numeric sequence terminated by a semicolon. If it is not, then the ampersand is interpreted as plain text.

  4. (4)

    The xhtml standard forbids nested links. Curiously enough, however, the w3c's own famous validator is unable to detect such violations of the specification.

  5. (5)

    This is a meta-note, a note about notes. It is used to demonstrate the declaration of notes.
